I've been thinking a lot about risk recently.
Partly because of the new scar on my face,

4.text:
and partly because I'm sitting on Pulpit Rock,
in the south of Norway, with nothing between

9.text:
me and a 600 meter drop. It is a very very
long way down and it is very windy.

15.text:
But how risky is this, really? I mean, millions
of people have visited Pulpit Rock. It's not

20.text:
a difficult hike. Families with kids come
up here all the time. And yet, in living memory,

25.text:
only one person has ever fallen off it. Walking
up here is probably more dangerous. Driving

31.text:
to the base of it certainly is. And yet this
has been called one of the world's scariest

37.text:
Humans are bad at assessing risks. That's
not news, you know that. But would I still

41.text:
be here, would he still be sitting on the
edge, if the consequences were different?

46.text:
Let's say, theoretically, that at some future
point humanity has cured all disease, including

51.text:
ageing. No one gets old, no one gets ill.
Technically, you are immortal, but you can

57.text:
still get hit by a car, or fall off a very
high rock.

59.text:
I did some maths. An average, modern, healthy,
western person has about a 1 in 2500 chance

67.text:
of dying from an accident every year. It's
a rough estimate. But those odds mean that

73.text:
one in five of those immortals won't live
to see 500 years. One in three don't see 1,000.

80.text:
Sure, that's a long life, but it's not immortality.
You still die.

85.text:
Transhumanists would say, well, they're able
to back up their minds, that all they need

89.text:
to do is "live long enough to live forever"
– that's Ray Kurzweil. But if that turns

94.text:
out not to be an option, then the only way
to survive would be to avoid all risks.

100.text:
Now, in English, we use the word "live" not
just to mean our bodies working, but to represent

106.text:
experiences like this. It implies that hiding
away in a bunker, avoiding risk, is somehow

112.text:
being less alive. But if you really had literal
immortality, if you thought you'd survive

119.text:
into eternity, would you live like this, take
those actually quite scary 1 in 2500 odds

127.text:
every year, knowing that, at some point, your
number will come up? Or do you hide yourself

132.text:
away, never leave a safe bunker, knowing you
won't interact with the world, but know you'll

138.text:
grow old with it, you will find out what the
future holds?

143.text:
Ultimately: which is more human: the desire
to experience, or the desire to survive?

149.text:
I don't know the answer, and I suspect it's
somewhere in the middle, because some old

155.text:
part of my brain, with millions of years of
evolution guiding it, has already made the

159.text:
decision for me. Because I am sitting on this
bit of the rock, and not out there.
